properties.Title: Civil Emergency, Update From Sk Provincial Emergency Communications Centre
properties.Summary:
Description: This emergency advisory alert is being issued for the province of Saskatchewan. All travelers returning from outside of Canada are subject to a mandatory 14 day self isolation order. Violation of the order may result in a fine of 2000 dollars.
Expires: 2021-03-03T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre, 2021-02-17T10:59:47-06:00, E13CAF2D-F525-5B74-06E5-B324A694A217
Area: Province of Saskatchewan
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls tonight and Friday. Snow squalls have developed between Wawa and Marathon south of Highway 17. The snow squalls are expected to move east into the town of Wawa and the Agawa region overnight. Travel along Highway 17 between Wawa and Agawa Bay may become hazardous overnight and Friday due to heavy snow and poor visibility. Accumulations in excess of 20 cm are possible. The snow squalls are expected to move south of the region late Friday. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-19T12:43:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-18T20:44:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1555120417.2021
Area: Wawa - Pukaskwa Park, Agawa - Lake Superior Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls may develop later this morning and continue until Friday morning. Travel along Highway 17 between Marathon and Wawa may become hazardous due to heavy snow and poor visibility. At this point, it appears that the heaviest amounts will remain south of the highway west of Wawa where amounts may exceed 20 cm. The snow squalls should move east of the region by late Friday morning. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-19T00:59:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-18T09:00:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2463592218.2021
Area: Marathon - Schreiber, White River - Dubreuilville, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow is expected for the start of the weekend. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Locations: most of Nova Scotia, including Halifax Metro. Time span: Friday evening until Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Snow will begin spreading across western Nova Scotia Friday afternoon, and then across the rest of the province Friday night. The snow will taper off from west to east during the day Saturday. Latest forecast guidance suggests that accumulations of 10 to 20 cm are possible. As this system develops further and approaches the Maritimes, snowfall warnings may be issued. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-19T11:41:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-18T19:42:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0505608445.2021
Area: Kings County, Annapolis County, Digby County, Lunenburg County, Queens County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County, Hants County, Colchester County - Truro and south, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County, Guysborough County, Antigonish County, Richmond County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold wind chill values between minus 55 and minus 60 will continue today. Wind chills will moderate today as the winds begin to ease and temperatures climb. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-19T01:34:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-18T09:35:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3565566507.2021
Area: Resolute
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. A pacific frontal system is generating snow over Kitimat area. Snow will change to rain this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: locally 10 to 15 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 70 km/h. Locations: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity. Time span: today. Remarks: Conditions are favourable for local intense snow squalls this afternoon. Conditions are expected to improve this evening as the flurries become less frequent and winds diminish. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-18T22:59:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-18T14:26:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2624228708.2021
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chills near -50 continue to affect Arctic Bay and Pond Inlet this morning. Conditions will remain bitterly cold on Thursday before beginning to moderate on Friday. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are expected by Friday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today and tonight. What: Snow. Total amounts of 5 to 15 cm are expected by Friday morning. Where: Portions of the Greater Toronto Area, particularly downtown Toronto, southern Etobicoke, Mississauga, Milton, and Oakville. This includes sections of the following highways: -Highway 403 -Highway 407 -Highway 427 -Queen Elizabeth Way -Gardiner Expressway When: Midday today through Friday morning. The steadiest snowfall is expected this evening. Discussion: Lake enhanced snowfall is expected to locally boost snowfall amounts to 10 to 15 cm in parts of the west end of the Greater Toronto Area. Accumulating snow could cause poor driving conditions, and impact the commute this evening and Friday morning. The localized nature of lake enhanced snow means that snowfall intensity and accumulations may vary considerably between nearby locations. Actions: Drivers should plan to give themselves extra time to reach their destination. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-19T08:15:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-18T16:16:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1765879207.2021
Area: City of Toronto, Mississauga - Brampton, Halton Hills - Milton, Burlington - Oakville
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls today into Friday morning. Snow squalls have begun to develop near Lake Superior and will persist into Friday morning. The strongest activity today is expected between Wawa and Marathon south of Highway 17. The snow squalls may move towards the town of Wawa later tonight into Friday morning. The heaviest accumulations are expected close to the shoreline west of Wawa where amounts may exceed 20 cm. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-19T08:16:07-00:00

Area: Wawa - Pukaskwa Park

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A strong frontal system moving across the BC coast is producing strong southeasterly winds with speeds of 90 to 110 km/h this morning. The winds will ease near midday when the front moves inland. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-19T00:59:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-18T12:26:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2273336997.2021
Area: Haida Gwaii, North Vancouver Island, Central Coast - coastal sections, North Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A strong frontal system will track across Haida Gwaii late tonight into early Thursday morning. The front will make its way into the north coast and northern Vancouver Island early Thursday morning then depart to the east by Thursday afternoon. The front will generate southeast winds at 90 to 110 km/h as it moves through these regions. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-18T23:59:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-18T09:58:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4239515559.2021
Area: Haida Gwaii, North Vancouver Island, Central Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow is expected for the start of the weekend. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Locations: southern half of Nova Scotia, including Halifax Metro. Time span: Friday evening until Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Snow will likely begin spreading across western Nova Scotia Friday afternoon, and then across the rest of the province Friday night. The snow will taper off from west to east during the day Saturday. Latest forecast guidance suggests that accumulations of 10 to 20 cm are possible. This system is still in early stages of development. The situation may change and it will continue to be closely monitored as it approaches in the event that warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-19T06:42:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-18T14:43:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1142078319.2021

properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chills near -50 continue to affect Arctic Bay and Pond Inlet. Clyde River will experience these same extreme wind chills tonight and Friday. Conditions will begin to moderate across the region on Saturday. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
